author: juneb
body:
In #2088 and others, we reported that provider-specific help (custom cmdlet help for providers) was not displayed. That problem is fixed.

However, from within a provider drive, you cannot get the generic (non-provider-specific) help for a cmdlet in the canonical way:

`Get-Help <cmdlet> -Path $null`

When you use this command, you still get provider-specific help for the cmdlet. 

If there is another way to get generic help for the cmdlet and we have abandoned `Get-Help <cmdlet> -Path $null`, we need to remove the instruction to use it from the docs, including [http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh847897(v=wps.630).aspx](http://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh847897(v=wps.630).aspx).

Steps to reproduce
------------------
1. In C:\> Get-Help Get-ChildItem
# Gets filesystem help for Get-ChildItem.
2. C:\> Get-Help Get-ChildItem -Path $null
# Still gets filesystem help for Get-ChildItem. Should get generic Get-ChildItem help.
3. cd cert:
4. Get-Help Get-ChildItem
# Gets certificate provider help for Get-ChildItem.
5. Get-Help Get-ChildItem -Path $null
# Still gets certificate provider help for Get-ChildItem.


Expected behavior
-----------------
C:\> Get-Help Get-ChildItem -Path $null
Gets generic (not provider specific) help for Get-ChildItem

Actual behavior
---------------
C:\> Get-Help Get-ChildItem -Path $null
Gets provider-specific help for Get-ChildItem


Environment data
----------------


comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
Pending a proper fix, here's how you can currently work around the issue:

```powershell
Get-Help Get-ChildItem -Path noSuchDrive:
```

A nonexistent drive apparently causes fallback to the generic topic.

comments.author: juneb
comments.body: That's cool, but the docs say that the canonical way to do this is use $null. So, if we decide not to fix it, we should change this to a doc bug.

title: Get-Help <cmdlet> -Path $null shows provider-specific help
